qas.question: What does being a Class 1 LED product mean?

answers.text: safe under all conditions of normal use

qas.question: What type of LED can possibly cause blindness?
What class are extremely bright LEDs listed as?
Which government advocated the banning of Class 2 LEDs?

plausible_answers.text: safe under all conditions of normal use

qas.question: What does being a Class 2 LED product mean?
What type of LED can't cause blindness?
What class are extremely dark LEDs listed as?
Which government advocated the suppoert of Class 2 LEDs?

context: The vast majority of devices containing LEDs are "<a1_0><b6_0>safe under all conditions of normal use<b6_0/><a1_0/>", and so are classified as "<a0_0><b5_0>Class 1 LED product<b5_0/><a0_0/>"/"LED Klasse 1". At present, only a few LEDs—<a2_0><b7_0>extremely bright LEDs<b7_0/><a2_0/> that also have a tightly focused viewing angle of 8° or less—could, in theory, cause temporary blindness, and so are classified as "<a3_0><b8_0>Class 2<a3_0/>"<b8_0/>. The opinion of the <a4_0><b9_0>French<b9_0/><a4_0/> Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES) of 2010, on the health issues concerning LEDs, suggested banning public use of lamps which were in the moderate Risk Group 2, especially those with a high blue component in places frequented by children. In general, laser safety regulations—and the "Class 1", "Class 2", etc. system—also apply to LEDs.
